Hello I am playing the Natural Number Game https://www.ma.imperial.ac.uk/~buzzard/xena/natural_number_game/?world=7&level=10 world 7 level 10 when I came across this: We proved earlier that (P → Q) → (¬ Q → ¬ P). The converse,
that (¬ Q → ¬ P) → (P → Q) is certainly true, but trying to prove
it using what we've learnt so far is impossible (because it is not provable in
constructive logic).

My question is this, since I proved https://github.com/ImperialCollegeLondon/natural_number_game/blob/master/src/game/world6/level8.lean here lemma contrapositive (P Q : Prop) : (P → Q) → (¬ Q → ¬ P) can I not just apply contrapositive (¬ Q) (¬ P) to get (¬ Q → ¬ P) → (P → Q)?
no because then you'll get ¬ ¬ P -> ¬ ¬ Q and in constructive logic ¬ ¬ P isn't the same as P!
Just don't ask. The constructivists are crazy ;-)
Fascinating and mind boggling! Gotcha, so that is where it breaks down. Thank you for the explanation (and fun game ;) )
Alex Kassil has marked this topic as resolved.
